lines: You are lying on a soft, furry blanket on the floor of a big room. You are on your back staring at shadows that sometimes creep across the ceiling. Every so often Mom or Dad passes by and makes a funny face. Your hands grope in all
directions, and your feet pat the floor gently, almost out of your control.
This maneuver is a little too difficult to accomplish at your present age. You can roll about half-way to one side.
You pucker your cheeks in and out and take short, quick breaths. The skin on your face feels alternately tight and loose. A person walks by and twirls their fingers at you.
You are too young to keep the person in view for a long time. Whoever it is, he moves past in a blur.
Your first SMILE! An important event. Your parents stand over you, mesmerized, as you practice your new skill.

I guess you are not feeling very cheerful. Unfortunately, your physical development is not yet to the point where you can roll over and give people the cold shoulder. You stare at the ceiling until you fall asleep.
Even though you are in a bad mood, this seems like great fun! Your mood takes a turn for the better. Someone walks by. You think, "Hey! Here I am!"
Poor baby. Your crying attracts the attention of your parents who bring you over to the couch and cuddle you until you fall asleep.
You must be thinking, "Get me off this cold hard floor!" Unfortunately, you aren't strong enough to roll over yet. You grunt and groan, cry for a few minutes, then fall asleep.
You're still too young to talk, but you make some noises. ("Ooooo, oooooooh, aaaaaaah, aaaaaaaak.") This brings some attention and a brief lift from the cold floor.

You think, "GET ME OFF OF HERE!" and "I WANT FOOD!" Babies your age have no control over their impulses. Your cries are a sign of discontent. Whatever happened to that nice warm swimming pool you used to relax in?
